newsitem.title: CANADA: Bid target Wascana's strategy on track - CEO.
newsitem.headline: Bid target Wascana's strategy on track - CEO.

text.p: Wascana Energy Inc., facing a hostile C$1.7 billion ($1.3 billion) takeover bid from Talisman Energy Inc., can build on strong 1996 financial results with even more impressive gains this year, Wascana's chief executive said on Friday.
Frank Proto, head of Wascana, said the Regina, Saskatchewan-based company's two-year-old turnaround strategy of aggressive oil and gas drilling and land buying in western Canada was well on track.

"This really began in 1995, the first year that Wascana replaced its annual production through the drill bit and that momentum just continued to grow and build during 1996," Proto said in a conference call.
"It shows that the plan we put in place is working. It shows that it's one of the well-executed plans and it's getting results for shareholders."
Before Calgary-based Talisman announced the bid on Feb. 12, Wascana had suffered with lackluster stock market performance, but had recently been touted by analysts as a turnaround story.
The company, known for its extensive heavy oil production in the province of Saskatchewan, on Thursday reported sharply improved financial and operating results for 1996.
With its talk of future prospects over the past two days, Wascana appeared to be serving notice that it may not simply roll over for Talisman.

However, Proto said he was unable to discuss the takeover situation -- including whether Wascana was actively seeking out prospective white knights -- until the firm received and reviewed Talisman's formal bid document.
"To date, no offer has been received and our board of directors will be meeting after that offer has been received to make those kinds of decisions," he said.
Talisman plans to offer C$18.50 ($13.69) cash or 0.41 of a Talisman share for each share of Wascana and is expected to mail its offering circular on Monday.
It would be the largest takeover since 1994 in a Canadian oil and gas sector currently frought with merger frenzy.

Proto said he expected Wascana's oil production to average 65,000 barrels a day in 1997, up from 51,400 barrels a day in 1996. Natural gas output was projected to average 235 million cubic feet a day in 1997, up from 200 million cubic feet a day in 1996. He also predicted dramatic gains in earnings and cash flow in 1997.
Talisman spokesman Dave Mann said his firm would likely be in a position to respond on Monday to any impact on its bid from Wascana's financial results and forecasts.
Wascana stock on the Toronto Stock Exchange closed down C15 cents (11 cents) on Friday to C$18.45 ($13.65). Talisman shed C30 cents (22 cents) to close at C$44.45 ($32.89).
